titleStmt.title: Contributions to the Theory of Pictorial Form.
titleStmt.author: P. Klee

div.head: A. Winter semester lectures 1921-1922 Nov. 14, 1921
div.p: By way of introduction, a brief clarifi- cation of concepts. First, what the concept of "analysis" encompasses: In ordinary con- versation one usually hears mention of chemists' analyses. For instance, a certain preparation sells well due to its excellent effect. The manufacturer's profits make other manufacturers curious, and they take a sample of it to the chemist so that he can analyze it. He must proceed methodically in order to break the prepa- ration down into its component parts. To solve the riddle.
In another case, a stimulant proves to have grave consequences for health. Here also the chemist must be called upon to reveal the harmful components through an analysis.
In both cases the given substance is a whole composed of different, initially unknown
parts; the components are what is sought after.
In our business, the motives or inducements that lead us to make analyses are of course different. We do not analyze works that we would like to copy, nor works we have reason to distrust.

We investigate the paths that another has followed in the creation of a work in order, by becoming familiar with these paths, to get going ourselves. This type of examination should prevent us from regarding the work as something rigid, immutably fixed. By means of such exercises we can prevent ourselves from sneaking up on a finished work only to quickly pluck up what stands out the most and run off with it.
A special type of analysis is the

examination of the work through the stages of its emergence. I designate this type with the word "genesis." The first book of Moses, which deals with the creation of the world, is also called Genesis. There it is written what God created on the first day, what on the second, and so forth. The universe surrounding us undergoes a historical articulation.

We are makers, working practitioners, and hence it is natural that here we shall move chiefly in a formal domain, all the while not forgetting that before the formal beginning, or (put more simply) before the first stroke, lies an entire prehistory: not only, say, the yearning, the human desire to express oneself, not only the outward necessity to do so, but also a general human condition, whose orientation is called a weltanschauung, which, with an inner necessity,
urges its manifestation in this or that direction.
I emphasize this lest the misunder- standing arise that a work consists only of form.

But on the other hand, I must empha- size here even more that the most precise scientific knowledge of nature, plants, animals, the earth and its history, or of the stars is useless to us if we are not provided with all the tools for their representation; that the profoundest understanding of the synergy of these things in the universe is of no use to us if we are not also equipped with forms directed towards that purpose; that the deepest feeling, the most beautiful soul, is useless unless we have the proper forms at hand.

p.s: Here it means renouncing the excep- tional fluke that on occasion earns the dilettante honor with a successful work that

div.p: After these general premises, I shall begin where the pictorial form actually begins, with the point that sets itself in motion.

p.s: can, as an isolated case, shame the professionals.

div.p: After the pen or something else with a pointed tip is applied, a line promptly emerges. (The more freely it takes its jaunt initially, the clearer its mobile nature will be.)
But if I apply a line with the angular edge of some black or colored material, then a plane emerges (initially, and if the jaunt it takes is very restricted).

If we had a material with which to push planes forth with a similar effect, then we could inscribe such a notional sculpture in space.
But that is, alas, a utopia.
So let us tarry for the moment with the most primitive device: with the line. In the pre- history of peoples, where writing and drawing still coincide, it is the given element. Also our

children usually begin in this way. One day they discover the phenomenon of the mobile point, and one can scarcely imagine their enthusiasm. With the greatest of freedom, the pen initially moves wherever it pleases. Once these first works are examined, however, the discovery is immediately made that the paths traversed have now become fixed in ink. Now then, children who continue to take pleasure in chaos are of course not image-makers, but other children will soon progress to a certain order. The critique of the journeys made by the pen begins. The chaos of the initial play gives way to an incipient conformity to set principles and patterns.
The freedom with which the line is guided submits to the anticipated final effect. Now, out of caution, one begins to work with very few lines to achieve an effect. One remains primitive.

Yet one cannot persist stubbornly in this primitivity. One will have to discover a means of enriching the meager end result without destroying or blurring the simple, clear arrangement. One must classify.

div.p: With all these examples, the principal line goes forth freely and unbound. It is, so to speak, a stroll taken for its own sake. Without a goal.
This new line, however,

has a deadline, it wants to go as fast as possible to 1, then to 2, to 3, and so on. One might say it is rather more like running errands than taking a stroll. The straight lines indicate as much. But both the free line and the line with a time limit are of a purely active type.
Linear medial
In these new cases the time-constrained line circumscribes the figures of planes like a triangle or a square.
Or, here, a circle and an ellipse.

As a line it is marked by its calming character and by its lack of a beginning or an end. Considered in elemental terms (as an action of the hand) it is certainly still a line, but once it has been completed, the mental image of linearity is superseded immediately by that of planarity. With it, the mobile character also disappears (no one looking at the disk of the moon would attempt to ride a carousel around its perifery), replaced by the notion of the most complete quiescence (chiefly in the instance of the circle).
Linear passive
The lines in this case have an entirely passive character.
One indeed also sees lines, but it is not a matter of linear actions but of the linear results of planar actions. The line is not made but rather is suffered.

Running contrary to the trajectory of this short account of the line, and at the same time contained within it, is an account of the plane. When active, the line divided [it] into imaginary planes. In between, the plane-character pushed its way forth; it then became active when the line was designated as passive.

The plane, when purebred, is the element at rest. But if it starts to move,
then it approaches the line-character.

The further
the line AB moves forth, the thinner the described plane becomes in relation to its length, until finally one may speak of the coincidence of A and B, with which we have arrived once again at the active line.
Exercise: The Violin. Models: one cello, two violins.
Opening words: the violin as a perfect form, as a work of art, as an independent personality (not a machine). The view, for example, of Picasso, Braque, and the current Parisians.
Analytical beginnings proposed for those who are unsure; afterward, a freer compositional control with the present forms. Tacit wish: the freest compositions, more about the violin qua violin.
Results, for the time being, of a more analytical nature.
We were occupied 14 days ago with, among other things, the free line. I chose as an example a type that corresponded to a relaxing walk, without an express purpose, without an express goal.

This line had a certain inherent quiescence and harmony, and as a theme in a composition its realization would have required accompanying forms and so would have corresponded more to the folk- song form in music than to a more artistic form.
Sure enough, only accompanying forms or substitute forms joined the inherently quiescent line,
accompanying forms, in part (fig. 1), of absolutely converging character; or (fig. 2) of effectively converging character;
or (3) of effectively converging nature while maintaining the independence of the accompanying line, rather like the path
of a person with his or her dog running about freely.

The essential difference between this new construct and the previous examples of convergence is best illustrated if we think of each line, for instance, as the path taken by a person. You can speak of friendship in the previous examples; there is no drifting apart. But with this new divergent example we see our fellow stroller crossing our path just once, at point D.

Let us imagine this (fig. 5) to be railway tracks. Now, is there not something very misleading about this? Because these lines are truly divergent enough! Railway tracks that are constantly spreading further apart would result in the loveliest derailment. Or, if you took the opposite direction:
How does this happen, then? Well, without noticing, we have stepped out of the concept of planarity into the territory of space, into the third dimension. We are doing perspective.

Last time, we established with regret, first of all, that we have no kind of spatial writing: Unlike the movement from points to lines or the movement from lines to planes, we cannot analogously move planes forth with any visible effect, so as to produce solids. We must therefore make do with perspective.
But it will not take long to explain nor prove difficult if we confine ourselves to its principal features. And the explication of the inherent phenomena is quite remarkable!

These (fig. 7), then, are railway tracks. Railway tracks lie on crossties. How do I depict this? If I had drawn tracks on the plane, like a surveyor or carto- grapher, then we would have the image of two parallel lines,
and the ties would be placed at regular distances.
Represented spatially, however, this graphic image looks fundamentally different. The distance between the ties increases noticeably, as most Europeans know, towards the foreground.
The front of the locomotive stands at a right angle to the plane lying between the tracks. (We have thus right at the outset projected the greatest spatial height.)
Now, in this new third dimension we can imagine more new angles and planes (so the new plane
in fig. 11 stands at a right angle to the plane in fig. [10]),
and we arrive finally at the construction of a space into which we can walk standing upright.

Once again we begin by imagining the rails but limit ourselves to one tie lying far in the distance and another tie lying very near: that is, only two ties. We divide both ties into the same number of equal parts; here, for example, in three places.
In this manner we can go from crosswise graduation to grad- uation lengthwise and see before us in perspective the plane of a floor depicted with five parallel lines.
Which line stands out in particular?... Naturally, the middle one (from 2 to 2)
And in what capacity? As the vertical.
What does this vertical indicate? That at the point where it stands we ourselves have also stood.
If we take a step to the left, then the vertical shifts to point 1, and the plane of the floor takes this shape in the projection.
While with a vantage point at no. 3, the result is this new image of the projection.
When I travese such a plane, the vertical remains vertical, as long as I don't leave the line, and the other lines radiate towards me.
But if I leave the line, then the image deflects towards the opposite side in either case.
(And now, incidentally, we have made our acquain- tance with the phenomenon of counter-motion!!)

Now we want
to stand still again and so proceed as before with cross wise graduation. And the result is this image (fig. 21).

Again a space that we can walk into. I ask you to pay particular attention as well to the side walls. Just as on the plane of the floor the vertical assumed special importance, here the horizontal does.
What does this horizontal mean? (Now, the answer is almost ripe.)

Inside the now familiar space I have constructed a second one that offers the eye a view of its upper plane. Hence, one can speak more aptly of a volume than of a spatiality that ends within our eye's visual field, since actual spaces extend beyond our visual field. (We are inside them.) Thus, a volume that offers the eye a view of its upper plane.
In this case the volume does not offer a top view of its upper plane. If we assume it is made of glass, then it offers, on the contrary, a view of this plane from below.
The other horizontal plane our eye sees from above is lower than our eye; it lies below us.
In this third case, however, something special occurs. The eye is unable to re- cognize the upper plane as such, whether from above or from below; rather, it appears

as a horizontal line.
The volume is thus exactly as high as our eye.
(Splitting hairs, one could add that the lengthwise and crosswise graduation coincide.)

What is valid for this horizontal plane is logically valid also for the corresponding horizontal lines on both side walls. These horizontal lines at eye level appear again as horizontal in the perspectival projection.
So the answer is there. It is: "eye level."

The person, or the bearer of the gaze, may now stand in front, at A, or further back (like at B, C, D); from each of these vantage points the phenomenon of the horizontal occurs. One can conceive a large plane extending through all these points, A1 to D1 (a plane that, as demonstrated above, one can never see): the plane of the horizon. Remaining at point A1, for example, a huge circular disc.
This horizon-disc separates the entire visible space into an upper and a lower part, as if we found ourselves in a large round can that divides into can and lid.

This sign corresponds to the edifice of the human being, taking into account the earth's attraction. The feeling for the vertical is alive in us so that we do not fall, and if we must, we correctively stretch out our arms so as to again balance out the error. In exceptional cases we extend the horizontal, like the tight-rope walker with his balancing pole.

Note: The questions already raised pertaining to perspec tive and everything else that seems worth knowing can all be verified or investigated by means of a very simple apparatus. A pane of glass is brought into a fixed vertical position and placed near the eyes in front of the object to be projected. The observations must be made with one eye, fixed in its position. With ink or grease pencil the important essential lines of the object are drawn onto the pane of glass. Lines recorded on a pane of glass that is not standing vertically will be seen as incorrect, distorted images. Similar distorted images are produced by photographers who, from a low angle, take pictures of an object that can be easily controlled in perspective, for example, a house. To be precise, such images are not at all false objectively. (or logically)

are closer to the eye than the upper windows and there- fore are wider. But that is where a human being objects, because one wants to have the horizontal and the vertical fixed so that one does not begin to wobble, to get dizzy. The value of this whole procedure lies simply in the possibility of controlling, of monitoring. Drawing in correct perspective has therefore no value, because everyone can do it in this way.

December 12, 1921
We were left standing with the tight-rope walker and his balancing pole, as the extreme realiza- tion of the symbol of the equilibrium of forces.

We had derived this symbol from the rudiments of perspective theory, as the distinctive sign for the meaning of vertical and horizontal. The extension of the (seen) horizontal line onto the horizontal plane or, in short, onto the horizon, brought us the spatial extension of this symbol:

Today I would like to make the weighing of forces on either side the object of our investigation, namely, those forces that result from the earth's force of attraction, in other words, the weighing-up of weights. Forces of this kind are closest to us, since we ourselves are physically subject to these same laws of weight. For this, we still want to assume the solid ground on which we usually stand, and not (as happens exceptionally) go into the water or indeed the air.
As an instrument for this weighing, a pair of scales can be as useful to us as it is to the grocer in his shop.

A set of scales looks roughly like this. It weighs two weights against each other and, as there are only two, they can operate in a plane. For, wherever they are located in space, I can always bring two points into one single plane. (Supposing)
Fully spatial scales would look like this:
In this case, a set of spatial scales that extends over three axes, AB, CD, and EF. With these scales one can ascertain the weights on the walls of a space constructed as a hexagon (fig. 6).
*Supposing the one plane has been correctly weighed, then we can bring the scales into a new position and against the first plane weigh a second one opposite.* (a fully... etc.)
With this now no longer entirely simple little machine, it would be unwise to make our first experiments, and you will agree with me that we are justified in limiting ourselves to the plane.
It is the same whether the set of planar scales is standing or hanging (figs. 3 and 3a); what is essential is the cross made by the horizontal with the vertical. This is the spirit of the scales,
and we can leave out the pans without detriment.
If we disturb the scales on one side by overloading,
then the image changes in this way:
If we correct it with a counter-load,
then it looks like this:
What is new is this cross:

Now, I remind you of the complementary relationship of lines to planes, as I presented it the time before last. The planes on which this kind of play of forces occurs are usually bounded, for example,
a quadri- lateral like this:
and with the new cross, like this:

Bearing in mind that complementary relationship, this figure (13a) permits two conceptions, one linear and one planar. Conceived in terms of lines, it is a quadrilateral with both diagonals; in terms of planes, it is a quadrilateral divided into four triangles. These four triangles arrange themselves, particularly if we do not take the quadrilateral as a square, as two pairs of triangles lying opposite each other.
It is characteristic of their position that they thrust against each other with their tips and, in fact, with the force of impact directed vertically and horizontally.

figure.figDesc: The scales are here again. (fig. 18)

div.p: The primitive simplicity of this case of a balancing act has allowed me to proceed symbolically, so to speak. The result is of a symmetrical nature, because the same kind of weights are on both sides.

A state of equilibrium diverging from symmetry could be illustrated with the image of a pair of scales with, for example, two one- pound weights in one pan and, in the other, one 750-gram weight and one 250-gram weight.
But we will now have to leave the matter there. We must operate with pictorial elements by means of which the feeling of weight can be discussed.
First of all, some cases in which we certainly cannot speak of equilibrium.
20) Difference in extension, accumulation of energy on the right side through addition.
21) Difference in tone value, additional load of black energy on the right
22) Difference in chromatic tone value, additional load of color energy on the right
23) Difference in color value, additional load on the left because of the color character.
Let us proceed to the corrections. For fig. 20, we reach into our element box, into the line compartment, and place what is missing on the left.
For figure 21, we reach into the black tone compart- ment and add a small black square next to the light gray square.
For figure 22 we reach into the red tone compartment and proceed accordingly.
For figure 23 we reach into the pure color compartment and load the blue side, which is too light, with some yellow, perhaps?

It is certain that with the correctly measured dose on either side, we can consider equilibrium to be established, that is, an equilibrium that is no longer identical with symmetry. In order, however, for either side to be identified with certainty as part and counterpart, so to speak, surely something beyond this rather rough comparison is needed. A local imperative must intervene, one which cannot be avoided in our assessment. Every conclusive example goes fundamentally beyond a loose comparison:
Here such a local imperative has intervened, i.e., a particular idea underlies the position of the energic weights: Example of configuration

The axis AB, overloaded with the heavier red, has sunk to A and risen to B. Originally it lay horizontally (a-b). Both these axes, the original ab and the new AB share a single point in common, the point C. C is therefore the pivot. The result of this rotation of the axis is that red, on the left, is lower than light red, on the right. Now to compensate, dark red intervenes and will be in a position to provide the compensation.
A little drama of horizontals, construed anthropomorphically: I began to totter towards the left and reached out towards the right with my hand, trying to find a hold somewhere so as not to fall.
Or, by transferring the action onto the vertical:
The upper part of the body is too heavy; the vertical falls to the left if the correction below does not occur in time. One widens the base by stretching out the left leg.
The character of both these schematic compositions is centric, i.e., their arrangement is in reference to a center point.

Thinking now of such compositional actions repeated many times from below to above, we then have a series of such center points, one above the other, and we can then no longer speak of a centric arrangement. This series of points C takes on the appearance of a spinal column, as you will see.

I is thought of as a socle, II as the first stone on this socle, laid just at the tipping point. One can imagine the force that would tip it over having its expression in the arrow, ‚Üí, and its measure in the weight, w.

If one now thinks of this sort of construction carried forward, alternating from left to right, then an actual tipping will be avoided. Each stone pulls, so to speak, at the vertical axis, each wants to make the horizontal pivot at its point CI or CII or CIII.
By unraveling the basic schema of this building method, we obtain the following constructs (in addition to other possibilities):

Buildings of this kind (like towers) are comparable to a person standing. As the effort to maintain his or her balance becomes taxing, the person sits down and reduces this task by about half. If he or she leans back against something, then only a remnant of the balancing

activity is left, but nevertheless still a remnant, because someone who has fainted might fall off a chair in certain circumstances. This remnant only disappears completely in the recumbent position. The person becomes a building block.
Compositions of a recumbent character have, in comparison to the vertebral construction (figs. 27 and 28), a certain becalmed quality.
The base widens, and with it so does the

horizontal, at the cost of the vertical. An appreciable reduction of tension occurs--an epic tempo in comparison to the drama of the vertical character--which naturally does not exclude a weighing-up on each side. The vertical is always still there!
The weighing-up only stops when the diagonal ceases, when the scales freeze in place, e.g., with this most primitive rhythm of the structural, where there are only horizontal or only vertical lines:
I am arriving at the essence of the weight of pictorial elements. If I ask,
"Do you consider this square heavy or light?" As such, there is no definite answer. For if the answer were "light!" and I added a second much smaller square,

it would thus immediately invalidate the hasty reply, for now the square makes an impression of being considerably heavier. One can now say that the large square is heavy in comparison with the small one and that the small one is light in comparison with the large one. Relativities.

Now, however, both these weights can hold their own against one another. And why? One is lighter in terms of energy, though much larger, and the other is very heavy in terms of energy, though small in size.
One cannot decide so lightly which is actually heavier. In this undecided case, the assumption of the given equilibrium is intuitively close at hand, implied in our indecisiveness.
The effect of weight is more a question of quantity on the left, in comparison to the right, where it expresses itself more qualita- tively. Relativities!

The assumption that black is heavier than white only applies as long as we move on the white plane as a precondition. In this case, if we disregard color, black is the device for developing energy. The blacker the energy, the heavier the impression of weight compared to the white plane. Again, a relativity.

If, by contrast, one takes a black plane as given, then a black energy cannot therefore express itself on that plane, precisely because its weightiest development, deep black, would not stand out at all. Therefore in this case, as long as we disregard color, white is the given energy, and it is precisely the brightest white that has the qualifications for producing the heaviest effects.
On a gray plane of medium tone, black and white can rival each other as energies.

Outdoors, for example in the countryside, one may assume a white plane as given if the weather is foggy. The things that are closest by (and thus the heaviest) stand out to us as particularly dark, whereas heading into the distance everything grows gradually
lighter until finally it merges entirely with the background.
In the dark of night, areas of brightness, such as illuminated windows, have the strongest and heaviest effect.
And on a normal day, one can observe the interaction of dark and light against a medium tonality.

In physics one speaks of specific weight in comparison to water. In our case, there are several specific weights, in comparison to white, to black, or to the average of the two (and to every gradation between).
After that, the world of colors introduces yet more relationships: colors on a red background... colors on a violet background... etc.
January 9, 1922
Exercise in initial capital letters (Antiqua). a) intrinsically balanced letters, like H, A, M, etc. b) letters lacking equilibrium, like P, F, etc. The composition to be arranged in solemn stasis.
January 16, 1922
Last time, the opposition between compositional and structural characters became evident.
Structural rhythms of the lowest degree of development appeared, which find their numerical expression in the aggregation of simple units:
and
Addition of simple units in a linear direction.
Crossing both directions produces this new structural image,
which can be described as the addition of units in the direction of two dimensions. This image, though extending through its two dimen- sions, still remains
at the lowest position in the order of structural characters.
A step higher, there is this new structure:
or this structure:

(figs. 4 and 5) If one compares their numerical expression, both structures resemble each other to a tee. The difference lies only in the choice of means for representing them pictorially. (fig. 4) The first case makes use only of the measures "single segment" and "double segment," while the second case makes use only of the weights, light and dark. In other words, measure in one case, weight in the other.N Or, in one case, a force that achieves the greater output, 2, without a greater effort but through a doubling of the time in which it occurs; and in the other, a force that works towards its greater output only with doubled energy.
Note: I would like to provide a picture frame with a hook; I measure the upper horizontal very accurately to find the center. I attach the hook exactly at the midpoint
and am convinced that now nothing else is lacking. Yet in the end, the picture still hangs crooked on the wall.

And why is it hanging crooked? Because the density of the wood is not uniform or because the glass is possibly thicker and heavier on one side. In short, I have made the mistake of measuring instead of weighing.

In another case I want to cut a very long wooden pole into exactly two halves. It seems to me that the simplest way is to balance the pole on a sharp edge. I am pleased with my sharp-wittedness and happily saw on. The result: two pieces of entirely different lengths. Why, then? The wood must have varied in its thickness and weight, and I made the mistake of proceeding by weighing instead of measuring.
So, on the one hand, measure; on the other, weight. I return to both our higher-order structures and consider the numerical series they share in common: 1 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 1 + 2, etc.
This series does not change if I represent it thus: (1 + 2)+(1 + 2)+(1 + 2)+(1 + 2), etc.
This, then, equals: 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 And this is the regular repetition of a type of unit (tripartite), and therefore again a purely structural case.
This algebraic maneuver corresponds pictorially to the following conception:
thus 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 = I + I + I + I + I, where Roman numeral one stands for a higher unit.

the horizontal sums present the same scenario; thus, I+I+I, etc. in the horizontal direction.

div.p: Thus, the entire square of this structure is articulated as joined pairs of two neighboring squares in the horizontal and vertical:
Whereupon there emerges an articulation into four sided, four-part units with a value of six: 6 + 6 + 6 I + I + I + + + 6 + 6 + 6 or I + I + I + + + 6 + 6 + 6 I + I + I
This regular repetition of a higher unit is, however, characteristic of a structural formation.

(figs. 7a and 8) A variant of the concept of this chessboard structure with emphasis on the diagonals offers us a linear structure with two different qualities of line, which again can be read reciprocally as the rhythm of four-part units. These units take the shape of squares standing on their vertices.
And in this way one can invent fascinating higher-order structural motifs; as soon as any repeating rhythm can be verified, its structural character is established.

It cannot be claimed that such rhythms are inherently of an organic character. This is confirmed at a first glance at the corresponding numerical series. Every organism is an individuum, a word meaning "indivisible." That is to say, one cannot remove anything from it without altering the character of the whole or, in the case of living beings, without impairing the function of the whole or even stopping it outright. Likewise, nor can one add something to it.

Our numerical series and numerical complexes retain their sub-organic, dividual character if we, instead of 1 + 1 + 1 + 1, put: 1 + 1 + 1, or: 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1; instead of 3 + 3 + 3 + 3, put: 3 + 3 + 3, or: 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3; instead of 6 + 6 + 6 put: 6 + 6 or: 6 + 6 + 6 + 6 + + + + + + + + + 6 + 6 + 6 6 + 6 6 + 6 + 6 + 6 + + + + + + + 6 + 6 + 6 6 + 6 + 6 + 6 + + + + + + + 6 + 6 + 6 6 + 6 + 6 + 6
One might be reminded, from Natural History, of primitive organisms made of few cells or of those single-cell bacteria that are only noticeable in great masses.

A great advantage, however, also lies in the individual insignificance of the structural rhythms: they can be easily arranged into an organic, individual whole, supporting the organism's being--without opposing it anywhere. *Note*
Individual rhythms, conversely, cannot be reduced to one or to similar numbers but must stop inexorably at proportions like 2:3:5 or 7:11:13:17.

Note * They are therefore suitable for livening up deficient places in certain compositions; they have long been familiar as wallpaper patterns, and they are suitable for livening up the surfaces of books and portfolios in a neutral manner.

I now cross over to the domain of music. Here the bar is the fundamental structure. For the ear, the bar is to a certain extent latent, but it is nevertheless experienced throughout as a structural web on which the quantities and qualities of the musical ideas play out.
The standard meters are duple and triple.

div.p: The rare, off-kilter bars of five or seven beats are unequally wieghted two-beat bars: 2 + 3 or 3 + 4 or 3 + 2 (five) 4 + 3 (seven)

This representation of bar structure corresponds to the quantitative conceptualization; it is the translation of the absolute measures of time into the absolute measures of length (mensural-rhythmic). Inherent to it is the shortcoming that, with just the length measures themselves, we cannot conclusively assign fixed values to the bar units (indicated by the bar lines).
Where? Where is the bar line? What is indicated by special signs like |? √ó? |? ‚Ä¢? ? They indicate that at the points where they are situated, different accentuations occur.

This shows us the path to another type of representation that will do better justice, from a sensorial point of view, to the essence of the bar structures. This representation would illustrate the quality of the parts of the bar especially clearly. It would be the representation of the relationships among weights, the qualitative treatment of the bar structures (weight-rhythmic)
By observing a conductor, we can obtain more planar images of bars. A quick look at the baton can reveal them to us.

In a four-beat bar the conductor beats the first value downward, the second up and to the left, the third from left to right, and the fourth from the right upwards to the starting point of the first value.

div.p: With this example (insert, fig. 22), which attempts to represent, pictorially and objectively, a thing that is simultaneously abstract and absolutely real, we can learn quite a few things: first of all, the possibility of this new representation in itself.
: Their relationship among each other, which pertains to their degree of individualization.
One moment it is two voices, the next it is three that sound together (and occasionally a single voice could even sound alone).

Both voices in the first bar (the second and third voices) differ greatly with regards to their individualization. The lower voice has a distinctly structural character in comparison with the higher voice, which remains individual.

When it enters later, the first voice begins somewhat lower than the second, seeking to leap over it, which at first it fails to do. Only after the short pause in the second voice does the first attain its coveted predominance. With the individualized entry of the first voice, the second is demoted to a structural character; due to its higher position in agreeable contrast to the third (which at this point dips slightly), the second voice makes an arc under which the first voice moves individually.
After the yielding pause, the second voice runs parallel to the third.
The third voice remains true to its structural character from the beginning up to the point where the second joins it in parallel; here one can detect a timid attempt at individuality.

A glance at the quantities of the example (insert, fig. 22) also shows that the mensural differences are based on simple and adjacent numbers. Were ratios of very small numbers to very large ones to occur in this example, then it would be a question of ornaments in music,
which, when employed all too triflingly, are called flourishes.

January 23, 192[2] Exercise: A composition of (I) individual and (II) structural rhythms. I and II are to be made organically, supporting each other reciprocally.
January 30, 1922

The time before last, I established the moment of repetition as a characteristic of structural rhythms. With a few structural examples that were fundamental due to their primitivity, we obtained, by measuring and weighing, series like: 1 to 1 to 1 to 1 to 1 or like 1+2 to 1+2 to 1+2 to 1+2 " " 11+10 to 11+10 to 11+10, for which we substituted the series I to I to I to I, with the Roman numeral one understood as a compound unit.
In the realm of two dimensions, in a plane, instead of these series we obtained complexes like I I I I I I I I I I I I I I I I

In contrast to these characters, we considered individual rhythms, taking as their basis numbers with which the moment of repetition was precluded. The prime numbers appeared to be particularly suited for this: 3 to 5 to 7 to 11 to 13 to 17 to 19 to 23, etc. In the following exercise, "Combination of structural

and individual rhythms," I warned against proceeding mathematically, because the theory is after all just an ordering of intuitively available things and plays only a retroactive role in the creative process--the role of criticism, brought to bear retroactively.
Some solutions to this exercise evinced first of all talent, and intelligence.
I should mention at the outset that no one discovered Columbus's fish. Columbus's fish
In some cases, an intimate fusion of individuum and structure was sketched out, the structure obligingly following the individuum's trail, step by step.

Let us assume that fig. 1 represents the individuum. Proof: no repetition. Like an upbeat it begins at A with seventeen, plummets by a value of twenty-three, bends at a wide angle to the right with thirteen, rises vertically with three, angles left with two, drops diagonally with nineteen, angles left

with fifteen to the endpoint Z.N (I ask, meanwhile, that the numbers be understood not quantitatively, but qualitatively.) The result is three circumscribed planes of a non repeating, and there fore individual, character: P5, P3 and P7

(to fig. 2) With fig. 2, the structural character comes into play. The plummeting vertical divides into five, five times,* the individual thirteen in a series of threes, followed by several twos, several threes, sixes, etc. *Pay attention to the points of intersection!

Regarding the combined figure (2), it still must be said that the measures of the individual rhythm are greater than the measures of the structure and that the individual (line-)trajectory is qualitative (or weighing), in comparison to the structure that is kept purely quantitative (measuring). *Note!

In this case (fig. 3) you can speak of a two-voiced trajectory, in which the individual theme is not repeatedly intersected by the structural theme, as in the previous example, but only now and then, not even in every segment.N Consequently, one cannot deny the structural theme a certain independence. It is aware of this and takes on a dynamic character in its trajectory. The individuum feels magnificent because of its higher distinctiveness, it requires no special accentuation of its ego, and it goes along separately, in quantitative stillness, flute-like, in spite of the companionship of the heavy structural

* I recently translated a musical construct into a pictorial construct. So now I can also think of the reverse and ask myself, how would our individuum, with its structure, sound as music? Undoubtedly as pure melody with purely accompanying subordinate forms.
instrumentation. The ratio of the measures in both characters corresponds to the ratios in the first example (fig. 2). The measures of the individual rhythm contain the higher numbers.
In this new example (fig. 4), if one disregards the verticals, the structural part may be analyzed very primitively as a re- peated ratio of 1 to 1 to 1 to 1 to 1 to 1. (horizontal parallels)

The verticals, a bit more developed rhythmically, introduce something new, namely, alternation in pairs: 2a + 2b + 2a + 2b (vertical alternation) (1+1) (1+1) (1+1) (1+1) (horizontal parallels) Or, in sum I to I In this linear representation of the structure, the manner of expression is purely mensural. If one thinks of the squares in alternating colors,* The individual part of this example shows us several individuums
* then one must take into account the fact that different colors indicate the strongest (psychological) dynamism and that great restraint is demanded of the individuum.

which differ from one another without repetitions. Where they are articulated, the articulation is based on individual numbers. Their expression is dynamic (weighing) in comparison to the purely mensural manner of expression of the structural part.
Comparison of the 3 examples. The first example (fig. 2) was melodic with structural accompaniment, therefore, a dominant individuum.
The second (fig. 3) was thematic in two voices, with dynamic accentuation of the relatively structural part, therefore, a delicate individuum. (delicate and devout)

This third example is a kind of emblem of the happy individuum or of happy individuums, which are able to arrange themselves rigorously over a wide area in conformity with the set structural pattern, without detracting from their individual character.
For a further example I am inspired by a very lovely little collage on glass that I got to see in the last exercise (fig. 5).
It consisted wholly of square pieces of paper--arranged freely alongside and overlapping each other, and freely positioned horizontally/vertically and diagonally--which created a lively

structural rhythm. Apart from their colorfulness, they produced a dynamic particularly rich in contrast, ranging from light to very deep dark, from the way in which they overlapped, because the light was meant to shine through it from behind, as with a glass window.

In the deep dark tonality, there was already a transition to the individual. However, the individuum received its full, most highly dynamic force of expression through the rhythmization of the squares into the complexes according to their color type: blue, red, violet, etc.
A highly dynamic individuum arose out of colors based on a tonal-dynamic structural rhythm. (* Another possi- bility

(fig. 6) Finally, yet another variant, in which an accentu- ated line, borrowed from some individuum, is divided individually, and on each segment of which the struc tural plane and the structureless plane face each other, in such a way that the two kinds of plane alternate, in sequences both horizontal and vertical. (Lest anyone think you must work according to rules.)

Up to this point, we have moved mainly in the formal terrain of culture. In our constructing, we worked from terrestrial, human assumptions, from the way in which we are affixed to the earth, from our restricted possibilities of movement, from the limited range of physics.
The main symbol of our activity was the pair of weighing scales, that horizontal governed by the vertical force of attraction of the ground upon which we must ever stand.

The simplest symbol for this force of attraction is the plumbline, the simple vertical. The weighing scales, however, take this perpendicular into account; the perpendicular is the criterion for its position of equilibrium.
One could thus say that the spirit of the scales is this cross:
Disruptions of the equilibrium of the scales produce the diagonal,
and their correction through a contrary disruption produces this new cross, the diagonal cross.
Now, where does this powerful force of attraction reside?
In the ground:
Or, if you know that this ground as a whole has the form of a ball, it resides at the center of this ball, at the center of the earth:

As a rule, physically, we cannot avoid this; as a rule, everything in this world must reckon with it. In particular, a construction's every stone is possessed by this force, whether they be supporting columns or the spans lying over them.

So, as a rule, we will repeatedly occupy ourselves with problems of statics. And our own physical-human dependence on this terrestrial force facilitates our ability to draw conclusions about our fellow sufferer of this force--the construction, the physical work.
In practice, our limited physical size and range of action compel us to start from the component, from the part of the whole.

That it is our lot to be thus bound should not discourage us from recognizing that above us, things can be otherwise, that there are regions where other laws hold, for which new symbols will have to be found, corresponding to movement that is looser and to places that are more mobile.
The intermediate realm of the atmosphere, or of its heavier sibling water, may lend us a mediating hand in order to later reach the vast space of the cosmos.

In water, as every swimmer can perceive, due to the new element and its new weight, the effect of the gravitational force determined by the earth's attraction works in the opposite direction, that is to say, upwards.
The diver, however, can with a little effort master the entire deep space of the water like a fish--or like a bird masters the entire upper realm of the air.

He must also make partial efforts, like the mountaineer or someone climbing stairs. Nevertheless, here the fixed points of adhesion, the footprints, become unnecessary. The rhythm of swimming movements
above or under water is more relaxed, smoother than the rhythm of walking on the ground or climbing a mountain or stairs.

The swimmer in the air (the pilot or the glider) must identify with his machine, and, integrated with it, he can indulge in new possibilities of movement. In a free-flying air balloon, there is altogether little to be done. One is left to forces like air currents or cooler and warmer air. The way in which air masses of differing temperature flow into one another allows for resistance-free movement.
In outer space, finally, there are no longer any caesuras, whether rigid or smooth. Here primal movement reigns, movement as the norm.
It is the whole that moves. The belief that we, as planet earth, are standing still and that the sun revolves around us was a delusion.
It is a delusion to think that the sun stands still and only we, the earth, move.
Suns have orbits set in motion; the planets have orbits arranged around the orbits of the suns.
It is the whole that moves.
